skill.name: readme-for-developers
skill.description: Write developer-oriented README as onboarding documentation. Use when creating/updating README, setting up new projects, or when new developers need to understand the codebase quickly. README = Entry point + Architecture overview + Working agreement.

skill.author: Doyajin174

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown templates and guidelines for writing developer onboarding READMEs. No scripts, network calls, filesystem access, or command execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: Writing a developer README is challenging without a clear structure. This skill provides templates and checklists to create comprehensive onboarding documentation that helps new developers understand a codebase quickly.
actual_capabilities: Generate 11-section README templates for developer onboarding
Create Mermaid architecture diagrams with code flow visualization
Build local development setup guides with step-by-step commands
Structure working agreements including branch strategies and PR rules
Produce debugging checklists with common issues and solutions
limitations: Requires user-provided project information to fill templates
Does not analyze existing codebase automatically
Cannot verify that generated documentation stays current
Templates are generic and may need customization for specific projects

use_cases.title: Standardize project documentation
use_cases.description: Create consistent README templates across team projects with clear entry points and architecture overviews.

use_cases.title: Onboard to existing codebase
use_cases.description: Use structured prompts to extract key information and build comprehensive onboarding documentation.

use_cases.title: Improve contributor experience
use_cases.description: Generate clear contributor guides with setup steps, code flow explanations, and working agreements.

prompt_templates.title: Basic README request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a developer README for my project. Include: system goals, local setup steps in 3 commands, and entry point files.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture focus
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a README section explaining the architecture with Mermaid diagrams for the main data flows. Include key code locations.

prompt_templates.title: Onboarding guide
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 'New Engineer Fast Path' section with links to the 5 most important README sections for getting started quickly.

prompt_templates.title: Full documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a complete 11-section developer README including: system overview, core flows, repo map, local dev setup, CI/CD, debugging, and working agreement.

output_examples.input: Create a developer README for a new Next.js project with PostgreSQL database

best_practices: Provide a 'New Engineer Fast Path' section with links to the 5 most critical sections for quick onboarding
Keep the README as a map and link detailed documentation in docs/ folder instead of bloating it
Include specific entry point files and their roles, not just folder names
anti_patterns: Writing marketing copy instead of technical information that developers need
Missing local setup steps or providing incomplete commands that require user guessing
Including every detail in one file instead of linking to docs/ for deep dives

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. All tools can generate structured README content using the provided templates.

faq.question: What project types work best?
faq.answer: Works for any code project. Templates adapt to web apps, microservices, CLI tools, and libraries. Adjust sections based on project complexity.

faq.question: How detailed should the README be?
faq.answer: Keep README as an overview map. Link detailed documentation in docs/ folder. Aim for new developers to understand the system in 30 minutes.

faq.question: Is my project data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based skill that generates templates. No code or data leaves your environment. Project details stay local to your AI session.

faq.question: Why use this instead of existing templates?
faq.answer: The 11-section structure covers all new developer questions. Includes specific templates for architecture, debugging, and team workflows that generic templates miss.

faq.question: How often should READMEs be updated?
faq.answer: Review READMEs when onboarding slows down or new developers ask repeated questions. Link to living docs that teams update as part of their workflow.
